text: After completing this section, you should be able to compose an objective function to be minimized or maximized, compose inequalities representing a system application, and apply linear programming to solve application problems. Linear programming is a mathematical technique to solve problems involving finding maximums or minimums where a linear function is limited by various constraints. The field began in the late 1930s and early 1940s and was used during World War II to maximize troop effectiveness and minimize casualties. Businesses later adopted linear programming to maximize output and minimize expenses; in short, it is a method for solving problems that involve finding a maximum or minimum where a linear function is constrained by various factors.

A graph consists of dots connected by lines; each dot represents an object and each line represents a relationship. Graphs help us visualize structures such as bus networks or social connections. In graph theory the objects are vertices and the connections are edges. A simple graph has vertices connected by at most one edge and no loops; a multigraph may have loops or multiple edges. Graphs can model anything from bus routes to computer networks and help us understand the structure of interactions among objects【701969766344517†L42-L74】.

In graph theory, trees are connected acyclic graphs that never loop back; family trees are a perfect example. A tree is a graph that is connected and has no cycles. Learning objectives for this section include describing and identifying trees, determining a spanning tree for a connected graph, and finding the minimum spanning tree for a weighted graph【710053469867937†L36-L57】.

The Travelling Salesperson Problem analyzes Hamilton cycles in complete weighted graphs to find the shortest route visiting a number of locations and returning to the start. You should be able to distinguish between brute force and greedy algorithms, list all distinct Hamilton cycles of a complete graph, and apply brute force and nearest neighbor methods to solve applications. A brute force algorithm lists every possible solution, while a greedy algorithm builds a solution step by step, making the apparent best choice at each stage【754608676384880†L36-L73】.

Combinatorial Optimization provides a thorough treatment of linear programming and combinatorial optimization. Topics include network flow, matching theory, matroid optimization, and approximation algorithms for NP-hard problems【473166586264932†L109-L113】.

section_title: Optimization Methods in Management Science – Course Description
text: This course introduces the theory, algorithms and applications of optimization. The methodologies include linear programming, network optimization, integer programming and decision trees. Applications cover logistics, manufacturing, transportation, marketing, project management and finance【92595363617296†L138-L150】.

section_title: Integer Programming and Combinatorial Optimization – Syllabus
text: The course is a comprehensive introduction to the theory, algorithms and applications of integer optimization. It is organized in five parts: formulations, complexity and relaxations; robust discrete optimization; algebra and geometry of integer optimization; algorithms for integer optimization; and mixed integer optimization【899910305359506†L123-L154】.

section_title: Heuristics and Approximation Algorithms – MIT Lecture
text: This lecture on heuristics and approximation algorithms outlines approximation algorithms, local search methods and simulated annealing. It defines an ε-approximation algorithm for a minimization problem: an algorithm H is an ε-approximation algorithm if it runs in polynomial time and returns a feasible solution whose cost is within (1+ε) of the optimal cost. Examples include heuristics for the travelling salesman problem such as the MST-heuristic and matching heuristic【500807336233429†L0-L80】.

The book supports inquiry-based teaching and covers topics including logic and proof, graph theory, combinatorics, sequences, generating functions and number theory【871046178027827†L62-L123】.

It explains that planning efficient routes is essential for business and industry, with applications like product distribution, laying fibre optic lines and social networks. Graphs consist of vertices and edges; simplifying a map into vertices and edges allows problems like traversing every street without backtracking to be analysed using graph theory【876328026777705†L3-L39】.

This key concepts section summarises graph theory topics: in a graph, vertices represent objects and edges represent relationships. The degree of a vertex is the number of edges meeting it. Graph structures include subgraphs, complete graphs and cycles. Euler circuits exist in connected graphs where all vertices have even degree; Euler trails occur when exactly two vertices have odd degree. Hamilton cycles are directed cycles that visit each vertex exactly once, and weighted graphs assign values to edges. Travelling salesperson solutions can be found using brute force or greedy algorithms【651486496646314†L104-L160】.

In the Hamilton Cycles section we look for circuits that visit each vertex exactly once. Early puzzles inspired by Hamilton cycles include a 19th‑century game involving a dodecahedron. The section introduces learning objectives: describe and identify Hamilton cycles, compute the number of Hamilton cycles in a complete graph and evaluate weighted graphs. Hamilton cycles are contrasted with Euler circuits; while Euler circuits visit all edges without repetition, Hamilton cycles visit all vertices without repetition【749150324427157†L36-L58】【749150324427157†L142-L147】.
